title: Traceability System
legalBasis: EU Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, Articles 18-20 on traceability requirements; EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004 on food business operator responsibilities; Royal Decree 191/2011 on the National Food Chain Control Plan
summary:
Traceability — the ability to trace food through all stages of production, processing, and distribution — is a legal requirement under EU Regulation 178/2002, Article 18. Food business operators must be able to identify any person from whom they have been supplied with food (one step back) and any business to which products have been supplied (one step forward). This 'one up, one down' traceability enables rapid identification and withdrawal of unsafe food products, limiting harm to consumers and economic damage to businesses.

For hospitality establishments, traceability primarily focuses on the 'one step back' component: knowing the origin of all food ingredients, maintaining delivery documentation, recording batch and lot numbers, and retaining this information for at least five years. In the event of a food safety incident or product recall, establishments must be able to rapidly identify whether they received affected products, when they were delivered, whether any remain in stock, and whether any were served to customers. Without adequate traceability, a localized contamination incident can become a widespread crisis due to inability to identify affected products.

Effective traceability systems need not be complex. At minimum, they require retaining supplier delivery notes, recording lot numbers for received products, maintaining organized filing systems, and keeping information for the required period. More sophisticated operations may implement digital traceability systems linking inventory management with supplier data, but the fundamental principle remains the same: know where your food came from and when.
keyPoints: Record supplier details for all food ingredients and products received
Maintain delivery notes showing batch/lot numbers, quantities, and dates
Keep traceability records for minimum 5 years as legally required
Have a rapid recall procedure enabling identification of affected products within hours
Label all opened packages and prepared foods with date and, where relevant, batch information
Maintain an approved supplier list with current contact and registration details
Ensure traceability extends to prepared dishes showing which ingredients were used

sections.heading: 1. Legal Requirements for Traceability
sections.content:
EU Regulation 178/2002, adopted following several major food safety crises in the 1990s, established comprehensive traceability requirements across the EU food chain. Article 18 requires that food business operators must be able to identify any person from whom they have been supplied with a food, food-producing animal, or substance intended to be incorporated into food. This information must be available to competent authorities on demand. The regulation recognizes that perfect end-to-end traceability may not be feasible, hence the 'one step back, one step forward' principle — each operator in the chain maintains links to their immediate suppliers and customers, creating a traceable chain.

For hospitality establishments, the primary traceability obligation is upstream: knowing where ingredients came from. The downstream component is simpler as most hospitality businesses serve directly to consumers (though caterers supplying other businesses have both upstream and downstream traceability obligations). The regulation does not prescribe specific traceability systems, allowing flexibility for businesses to implement appropriate methods. However, the information must be readily available — scrambling to find delivery notes in disorganized files during an incident is inadequate. Competent authorities expect that critical information can be accessed within hours, not days.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Required Information
subsections.content: Minimum traceability information includes: supplier name and business registration number (in Spain, the RGSEAA number for food businesses), product description (name, category), quantity received, batch or lot number (assigned by manufacturer or supplier), date of receipt, and use-by or best-before date where applicable. Delivery notes typically contain this information and should be retained systematically. Some products, particularly fresh produce or commodity items, may not have batch numbers; in these cases, record delivery date and supplier as the basis for traceability. For more detailed traceability, additional information may include: time of delivery, transport conditions, temperature on arrival, and staff member who received delivery. This additional data supports both traceability and HACCP monitoring.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Record Retention Period
subsections.content: Traceability records must be retained for periods longer than the shelf life of the products. EU guidance recommends minimum five years, and this has been adopted in Spanish regulations. The five-year period accounts for potential legal actions following foodborne illness incidents, which may take years to reach court. Records may be kept in paper or digital format provided they are retrievable and legible. If using digital systems, ensure regular backups and that the system remains accessible — migrating to new software should include data migration from old systems. Establish a systematic disposal schedule: after five years, records may be securely destroyed (respecting data protection requirements) to avoid accumulating excessive documentation.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Inspections and Verification
subsections.content: Competent authorities verify traceability systems during inspections. Inspectors may select a product present in your establishment and request that you demonstrate traceability: Who supplied it? When was it delivered? What was the batch number? Inspectors may also conduct mock recall exercises: they specify a hypothetical contaminated batch of a product and ask you to identify whether you received that batch, when, and what happened to it. These exercises test whether your traceability system functions in practice, not just on paper. Establishments should conduct internal traceability tests periodically, selecting random products and verifying that complete information can be retrieved rapidly. Regular self-testing identifies gaps before official inspections.

sections.heading: 2. Implementing a Traceability System
sections.content:
Effective traceability systems match the complexity of your operations. Small establishments with few suppliers and products may use simple paper-based systems. Larger operations with numerous suppliers, diverse products, and high turnover may benefit from digital inventory management systems with integrated traceability. Regardless of sophistication, the system must reliably capture required information, store it accessibly, and enable rapid retrieval when needed.

Implementation follows a logical sequence: identify all products requiring traceability (essentially all food ingredients), establish procedures for recording information at receiving, create organized filing or database systems for storing information, train staff on procedures and the importance of traceability, test the system through mock recalls, and review and improve based on test results. Traceability should integrate with existing HACCP and inventory management procedures rather than being a separate, burdensome system.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Receiving Procedures
subsections.content: Traceability begins at receiving. Receiving staff must: check that delivery notes accompany all deliveries, verify that notes contain required information (supplier, product, quantity, batch/lot numbers, dates), flag any missing information immediately with the driver or supplier, record any additional information required by your system (delivery time, receiving staff, temperatures), and file delivery notes systematically. If batch numbers are not on delivery notes, they should be visible on product packaging and must be recorded. Some operations photograph product labels showing batch numbers as backup documentation. For frequent deliveries from the same supplier, streamline the process with pre-printed receiving forms or digital systems while ensuring essential information is still captured.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Organization and Filing
subsections.content: Organize traceability documents for rapid retrieval. Logical systems include: chronological filing by receipt date (works well for small operations with few deliveries), filing by supplier (enables quick identification of all products from a supplier if recall affects multiple products), filing by product category (meat, fish, produce, dairy, dry goods), or digital databases searchable by multiple fields. Whatever system is chosen, it must be logical to users and maintained consistently. Designate a specific person responsible for maintaining the traceability system (typically the same person managing deliveries and inventory). Conduct periodic reviews (monthly) to ensure the filing system is current and complete. For digital systems, ensure data backup and recovery procedures are in place.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Linking Products to Dishes
subsections.content: Advanced traceability links ingredients to specific prepared dishes, enabling more precise recalls. If a contaminated ingredient is identified, detailed traceability reveals which specific dishes contained that ingredient and potentially when those dishes were served. This level of traceability is not legally required for most hospitality operations but can be valuable for large caterers, institutions, or high-risk operations. Implementation requires: standardized recipes showing all ingredients and proportions, batch coding of prepared dishes linking them to ingredient batches used, and records connecting specific dish batches to service dates or customers. This is complex and typically only implemented where justified by risk level or operational scale. For most restaurants, knowing that you received a contaminated ingredient and when is sufficient to enable appropriate response.

sections.heading: 3. Supplier Management and Approval
sections.content:
Traceability is only as good as the information provided by suppliers. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires food business operators to ensure food safety at all stages under their control, including supplier selection. While hospitality establishments are not responsible for their suppliers' production processes, they are responsible for sourcing food from legitimate, registered suppliers. Supplier approval and management processes ensure you work with suppliers who provide safe food and adequate traceability information.

A supplier approval system includes: verifying that suppliers are legally registered food businesses (in Spain, check RGSEAA registration), requesting documentation of food safety systems and certifications, evaluating supplier performance based on delivery quality and documentation, maintaining an approved supplier list updated regularly, and having procedures for addressing non-conforming deliveries or unsatisfactory supplier performance. Supplier management is a continuous process, not a one-time verification.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Supplier Verification
subsections.content: Before approving a new supplier, verify: legal registration as a food business (request RGSEAA number and verify with competent authority if uncertain), food safety certifications (ISO 22000, BRC, IFS, or equivalent for major suppliers), insurance and liability coverage, reputation and references from other customers, and ability to provide required traceability information. For small local suppliers (farmers, artisan producers), registration requirements may differ from large processors — consult with local health authorities about specific requirements for direct farm sales or artisan products. Documented supplier approval demonstrates due diligence and is evidence of responsible sourcing practices.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Ongoing Supplier Evaluation
subsections.content: Evaluate existing suppliers periodically (at least annually, more frequently for critical suppliers). Criteria include: consistent provision of safe, quality products meeting specifications, reliable delivery of correct products and quantities on schedule, proper delivery conditions (temperature, packaging, hygiene), complete and accurate traceability documentation, responsive communication and resolution of issues, and competitive pricing and terms. Document evaluations and maintain supplier performance records. Address performance issues promptly through communication with the supplier. If issues persist, consider alternative suppliers. For critical products or sole suppliers, develop contingency plans for supply disruptions.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Supplier Communication
subsections.content: Maintain good communication with suppliers to support traceability. Suppliers should: know your traceability requirements and provide necessary documentation, inform you promptly of any product recalls or safety issues affecting products they have supplied to you, provide advance notice of product changes, packaging changes, or supplier changes that may affect traceability, and respond promptly to inquiries during traceability exercises or incident investigations. Similarly, inform suppliers of any quality or safety issues with products they have supplied. Strong supplier relationships built on clear expectations and professional communication enhance both food safety and traceability effectiveness.

sections.heading: 4. Product Recall Procedures
sections.content:
Product recalls occur when food is found to be unsafe and must be withdrawn from the market. Recalls may be initiated by manufacturers, distributors, or competent authorities. When notified of a recall affecting a product you have received, you must act rapidly to: identify whether you received the affected product batch, determine whether any affected product remains in your facility, remove affected product from use and isolate it to prevent accidental use, inform competent authorities as required, and document all actions taken. Speed is critical — hours matter in preventing consumption of unsafe food.

A written recall procedure ensures consistent, rapid response. The procedure should define: who is responsible for managing recalls (typically the manager or food safety officer), how recall notifications are received and disseminated (email, phone, supplier contact), step-by-step actions to check for affected products using traceability records, procedures for isolating and marking affected products, notification requirements to authorities or customers, and documentation requirements. The procedure should include supplier contact list and authority contact information for rapid communication.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Responding to Recall Notifications
subsections.content: When a recall notification is received: immediately stop using or serving the product type specified in the recall, retrieve traceability records for that product type, check whether you received products from the specified supplier and batch/lot numbers during the specified date range, if affected products were received, determine what quantities remain in your facility and locate all remaining product, physically remove affected product from storage, preparation areas, and serving areas, clearly label affected product as 'RECALLED — DO NOT USE' to prevent accidental use, contact the supplier to arrange return or disposal as instructed in the recall notification, document all actions taken including: recall notification details, search results, products found, quantities, disposition, and staff involved, and notify competent authorities as required (some recalls require establishments to report their findings to authorities). If affected products were recently used or served, consider whether customer notification is necessary (particularly for allergen-related recalls).

subsections.heading: 4.2 Mock Recalls and Testing
subsections.content: Conduct mock recalls at least annually to test your traceability system and recall procedure. Select a product currently in your facility, identify its supplier and batch number, then challenge staff to: locate all traceability documentation for that product, determine when it was received and in what quantity, identify whether any remains in storage and where, locate the product physically, and complete this exercise within a defined time limit (typically 4 hours). Document mock recall results: time taken, completeness of information retrieved, any gaps or issues identified, and corrective actions needed. Use mock recalls as training opportunities, particularly for new staff or after procedural changes. Discuss results with staff to reinforce the importance of maintaining accurate traceability records.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Learning from Incidents
subsections.content: Whether responding to actual recalls or conducting mock exercises, analyze your performance to identify improvements. Common issues that mock recalls reveal include: missing or incomplete delivery documentation, batch numbers not recorded, filing systems disorganized making retrieval difficult, staff unfamiliar with recall procedures, and traceability information stored in ways not easily searchable. Address each identified gap through: procedural revisions, additional training, improved documentation systems, or digital system implementation. Product recalls and traceability failures in the food industry are reported regularly — learn from others' experiences as well as your own. Food safety newsletters and industry associations share recall case studies that provide valuable learning opportunities.

sections.heading: 5. Digital Traceability Solutions
sections.content:
Digital inventory management and traceability systems offer advantages over paper-based approaches: automated data capture (scanning barcodes or QR codes on deliveries), centralized searchable database accessible to authorized staff, automated alerts for products approaching expiry, integration with HACCP monitoring (temperature logs, cleaning records), simplified reporting and compliance documentation, and cloud-based systems accessible from multiple locations. For operations with high product volume and turnover, digital systems can significantly improve traceability efficiency and reliability.

Digital system selection should consider: ease of use (complex systems not used consistently are worse than simple systems used reliably), integration with existing systems (POS, inventory, accounting), mobile accessibility (staff should be able to input and retrieve information from smartphones or tablets in the kitchen), cost (initial purchase, implementation, training, and ongoing subscription or maintenance), supplier support and training, and data security and backup. Many hospitality-specific systems now include traceability as a standard feature integrated with inventory management.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Implementation Considerations
subsections.content: Successful digital system implementation requires: clear objectives for what the system must achieve, involvement of staff who will use the system in selection and configuration, comprehensive training for all users, parallel running of old and new systems initially to verify accuracy, establishment of data entry standards and validation rules to ensure data quality, assignment of responsibility for system administration and maintenance, and regular audits to ensure the system is being used correctly and data is accurate. Expect an adjustment period — digital systems require different workflows than paper, and staff need time to adapt. Provide ongoing support and be responsive to user feedback about system usability issues.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Data Security and Backup
subsections.content: Digital traceability systems contain business-critical information that must be protected. Security measures include: access controls limiting system access to authorized staff, password protection with regular password changes, data backup at least daily with secure off-site storage, disaster recovery procedures enabling system restoration if primary data is lost, and data protection compliance ensuring that any personal data (supplier contacts, staff information) is handled according to GDPR requirements. Cloud-based systems typically include automated backup and security features, but verify what protections are included and what your responsibilities are. For on-premises systems, implement and test backup procedures regularly — untested backups may fail when needed.

sections.heading: 6. Traceability for Prepared Foods
sections.content:
In addition to ingredient traceability, hospitality operations should consider internal traceability for prepared foods. When food is prepared in advance and stored, labeling should include: dish name, date of preparation, use-by date, batch code if applicable (linking to recipe or ingredient batches used), and any special storage or reheating instructions. This internal traceability serves multiple purposes: ensures FIFO rotation of prepared foods, provides information for reheating or service procedures, enables connection between prepared dishes and source ingredients if traceability investigation is needed, and demonstrates organized, professional kitchen management.

For operations preparing large quantities or supplying other businesses (central kitchen supplying multiple service locations, catering company supplying events), formal batch coding and documentation linking batches to ingredients is advisable. This enables precise recalls affecting only specific batches rather than withdrawing all production from a time period. The complexity of internal prepared food traceability should be proportionate to the volume, risk, and distribution of your products.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Labeling Standards
subsections.content: Establish consistent labeling standards for all prepared and opened foods: labels should be durable and legible, information should include all required elements (name, date, use-by), labels should be color-coded by day or category if helpful, staff should be trained on labeling requirements and provided with necessary materials (labels, markers, label dispensers), and labels should be applied immediately when food is prepared or packages opened, not retrospectively. Monitor labeling compliance regularly through kitchen inspections. Unlabeled foods present food safety risks (cannot verify age or rotation) and make traceability investigations difficult. Simple, consistent labeling practices integrated into workflow ensure compliance without excessive burden.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Recipe Management
subsections.content: Standardized recipes support traceability by documenting exactly which ingredients are used in each dish. Recipes should include: complete ingredient list with specific products and brands where relevant, quantities and proportions, preparation instructions, cooking temperatures and times, intended yield (portions or servings), and allergen information. Maintain recipes in a central, accessible location (recipe binder, digital database, kitchen management system). Update recipes when ingredient substitutions or procedural changes occur. Well-maintained recipe documentation supports traceability (what ingredients were in the dish served?), HACCP (what are the critical control points for this dish?), allergen management (which allergens are present?), consistency (ensuring dishes are prepared the same way regardless of who cooks), and training (new staff can reference recipes).

checklists.title: Daily Traceability Management
items: Verify that all deliveries are accompanied by complete delivery notes
Check that delivery notes contain supplier name, product details, quantities, batch/lot numbers, and dates
Record any additional traceability information required by your system (delivery time, staff, temperatures)
File delivery documentation immediately in the designated traceability filing system
Label all received products with date of receipt if not already marked
When opening packaged products, transfer batch information to container labels if relevant
Label all prepared foods with name, date of preparation, and use-by date
Document any product withdrawals due to quality or safety concerns
Ensure traceability records from 5+ years ago are being securely disposed per schedule
Check for any recall notifications from suppliers or authorities

checklists.title: Annual Traceability System Review
items: Conduct mock recall exercise: select random product and test complete traceability retrieval
Time the mock recall — can essential information be retrieved within 4 hours?
Review completeness of traceability documentation for past 12 months
Assess filing or database organization — is information readily retrievable?
Review supplier approval status and update contact information
Verify all current suppliers are registered and in compliance
Evaluate supplier performance and address any issues
Update recall procedure and supplier contact list
Train all staff (including new hires) on traceability procedures
Review integration of traceability with HACCP and inventory systems
Identify any system improvements needed and implement
Document the annual review and plan for next year

checklists.title: Product Recall Response
items: Immediately stop using or serving the recalled product type
Retrieve delivery documentation for the product category from relevant time period
Check whether received products match recalled supplier, batch/lot numbers, and dates
If affected products were received, determine quantities and locate all remaining product
Physically remove affected product from all storage, preparation, and service areas
Clearly label removed product as 'RECALLED — DO NOT USE' and isolate from usable food
Contact supplier following recall instructions for return or disposal
Document: recall details, search results, products found and their locations, quantities, disposition
Notify competent authorities as required by the recall notice
If affected products were recently served, assess need for customer notification
Review why affected products were received and whether supplier approval requires revision
Share lessons learned with all staff

bestPractices: Integrate traceability procedures with your existing receiving and HACCP monitoring procedures rather than creating separate, parallel systems
Designate one person as responsible for traceability system maintenance to ensure consistency and accountability
Use technology appropriately for your scale — simple operations may not need sophisticated digital systems; large operations benefit significantly from them
Conduct mock recalls annually including timing the exercise to ensure you can respond rapidly during actual incidents
Maintain good relationships with suppliers who will communicate proactively about potential issues before they become crises
Keep supplier contact information current and accessible including after-hours emergency contacts for recall situations
Share traceability importance with staff so they understand why accurate documentation matters, not just that it's required
Learn from recall incidents in the food industry even when they don't directly affect your operation — case studies provide valuable lessons

glossary.Traceability: The ability to follow food through all stages of production, processing, and distribution, tracking origins and destinations
glossary.One Step Back, One Step Forward: Traceability principle requiring businesses to know their immediate suppliers (one step back) and immediate customers (one step forward)
glossary.Batch Number: Identifier assigned by manufacturer to products produced under uniform conditions, enabling precise tracking and recall
glossary.Lot Number: Similar to batch number, an identifier grouping products with common characteristics or production period
glossary.RGSEAA: Registro General Sanitario de Empresas Alimentarias y Alimentos — Spain's General Health Register of Food Companies and Foods
glossary.Product Recall: Removal of food from the market when it is found to be unsafe, involving withdrawal from businesses and consumers
glossary.Product Withdrawal: Removal of food from the market before it reaches consumers, typically for quality rather than safety reasons
glossary.Mock Recall: Simulated recall exercise testing the ability to identify and locate specific products using traceability records
glossary.Competent Authority: Government agency responsible for food safety enforcement and official controls (in Spain, typically regional health departments)
glossary.Due Diligence: Demonstrable reasonable steps taken to ensure compliance and prevent issues, providing legal defense if problems occur despite good practices
